awd_titl_txt: Inter-scalar Responses to International Supply Chain Regulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Most digital products, such as cell phones, microprocessors and video game players, rely for their functioning on high charge-holding ores, which include columbite-tantalite (coltan), cassiterite, gold, and wolframite. The production and sale of these "digital minerals" has produced important economic opportunities for people in the developing world, which is where most of the ore is found. But digital minierals are also called "blood minerals" because illegal profits from their sale and trade have fueled the rise and perpetuation of some of the world's most deadly militarized conflicts.  The international community has responded to this problem with new laws, such as Section 1502 of the United States' Dodd Frank Act, which require that corporations try to monitor mineral sourcing. The laws are supported by certification schemes that try to assure that the minerals purchased by international corporations are acquired through legal supply chains and are conflict free. However, little is known about the impact of these regulations on the actual workings of the mineral trade or how they connect with the complexities of the lives, politics, and economies of local people who, if negatively affected, may try to subvert and evade regulation. This project seeks to fill this gap with ethnographic field research in the most important center of digital mineral production, the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo. 

Over the course of a year, University of California at Davis anthropologist, Dr. James H. Smith, will conduct ethnographic research with artisanal miners, traders, state officials, and others in key Congo mining towns in order to understand the effectiveness and local impacts of these regulatory and certification processes. The researcher is in an excellent position to carry out this research. He is fluent in Swahili and has previously conducted significant research on the social formations that have developed around coltan and cassiterite mining in the towns where the certification system is now being implemented. The researcher will collect data with a mix of social science research methods including participant observation, focus groups, commodity chain analysis, and interviews. The research will contribute significantly to social science theories of how globalization processes simultaneously integrate and disconnect people and nations at multiple scales. Findings from this research also will be important for helping to improve the viability of mineral regulation programs.

por.por_cntn:
The research for this project was carried out in the summers of 2015, 2016, and 2018, in the artisanal “3Ts” (tantalum, tin, and tungsten) mining towns of North Kivu, South Kivu, and Maniema Provinces in the Eastern DR Congo.  The research built on previous ethnographic research done at these sites, and was intended to understand the impact of the international regulation of conflict minerals legislation and reforms on the work and lives of Congolese involved in the mining and trading of these minerals.  In addition to examining the impacts of the de facto embargo on Congolese minerals commencing in 2010, this included researching the consequences of, and local responses to, new, corporate-sponsored “bag and tag” tracking schemes intended to ensure that the substances that end up in digital devices are “conflict free,” or free of blood.  The main tracking scheme was implemented by a consortium of smelters called the International Tin Research Institute (ITRI), in conjunction with a US NGO and the Congolese government.  Beyond the social and economic impacts of these changes, this ethnographic research also sought to understand how those involved in the trade understood and interpreted these interventions, and built on the PI’s earlier and on-going research on their understanding of the trade and their place in the global economy more broadly conceived.   Among other things, the research revealed the ways in which the discourse of “conflict minerals” and the ban on artisanal minerals stigmatized artisanal mining and benefitted foreign mining companies that were able to use this legislation to have artisanal miners removed from the sites they wanted to mine.  In some cases, these were sites that were first discovered and developed by artisanal miners, and to which mining companies were late arrivals.  In addition, the tracking schemes, which designated certain sites as “green,” or conflict free, had a number of unintended consequences, becoming a new quasi-legal system, superimposed on Congolese law, which effectively illegalized most Congolese artisanal mining, since the vast majority of mines were too far from the road, or too deep in the forest, to receive validation, even those artisanal mining was actually legal in most instances.  Congolese state officials were able to take advantage of this situation to expropriate the de facto “blood minerals” of miners and traders, which then usually became the property of the state, or the revenue of particular state offices.  Just as many technically “bloody” mines and minerals were actually not bloody, some technically “blood free” mines (like the one at Rubaya) were actually imbricated in and sponsoring violence, despite the fact that they were part of, and protected by, the tracking scheme.  Beyond these rather practical issues, the research built on my earlier research to elaborate a totally alternative and vernacular Congolese theory of progress and peace building, based on concepts that diggers refer to, broadly, as “movement” and “many hands touching money”.  In general, these concepts hold that conflict comes from people being excluded from the sources and methods of acquiring value, and holds that total exclusion leads to violence and war.  Rather, selective and thoughtful inclusion of those who could bring problems to others, or impede their movement, , is necessary to ensure a kind of “development” and “peace”.  This theory is directly in conflict with foreign conflict minerals interventions, which are about separating out “bloody” or “unclean” actors and spaces from “blood free” or “clean” ones.  Eastern Congolese interpret these foreign interventions in terms of their understanding of colonial history, which some refer to as an on-going process best captured by the phrase “the eyes of the world”, which refers broadly to foreign actors trying to identify and control Congolese wealth for themselves, while simultaneously limiting the movement of Congolese.  The research was published in the form of a 360 page book, entitled The Eyes of the World: Mining the Digital Age in Eastern Congo (University of Chicago Press, 2021).  The book has so far won the Association for Political and Legal Anthropology’s Best Book in Critical Anthropology Prize and been a finalist or runner up for the African Studies Association’s Best Book Prize and the Amaury Talbot Prize of the Royal Anthropological Institute.  A review of the book was published in the June 2022 issue of Foreign Affairs Magazine, which is unusual for anthropology books/ethnographies.
